facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 20,1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 20,1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Criminal Confirmation Case No. 18 of 1956 and Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated April 25, 1956, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Karimnagar in Criminal Case No. 9/8 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment and order dated April 25, 1956, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Karimnagar in Criminal Case No. 9/8 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 20,1956, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court at Hyderabad in Criminal Confirmation Case No. 18 of 1956 and Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated April 25, 1956, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Karimnagar in Criminal Case No. 9/8 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant tried under s. 302 IPC for murder of his brother Baga Rao and sentenced to death by Sessions Judge of Karimnagar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried by the learned Sessions Judge of Karimnagar in what used to be the State of Hyderabad  number part of the State of Andhra Pradesh , under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code, for the murder of his brother Baga Rao, and sentenced to death.

facts.text: Conviction and sentence affirmed by High Court of Andhra Pradesh on appeal and reference.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction and the sentence were affirmed by the High Court of Judicature of Andhra Pradesh, at Hyderabad, on appeal and on a reference by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Three other persons Lingarao (appellant's brother), Narsingrao (nephew), Mahboob Ali convicted under s.302 r/w 34 and 109 IPC to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: Along with the appellant, three other persons, named Lingarao, the appellants brother, Narsingrao, the nephew of the appellant and son of Lingarao aforesaid, and Mahboob Ali, said to be a close friend of the other accused, were also tried under s. 302, read with ss. 34 and 109 of the Indian Penal Code, and companyvicted and sentenced to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Baga Rao was an excise contractor, separated from brothers, partitioned family lands.

anchor.surface_text: The murdered man Baga Rao, who was an excise companytractor, had separated from his other brothers aforesaid, and had partitioned the family lands.

facts.text: Differences amongst brothers led to arbitration proceedings a few months earlier.

anchor.surface_text: There were differences amongst the brothers which had led to arbitration proceedings a few months earlier, which did number satisfy Baga Rao.

facts.text: Quarrel between Baga Rao and Lingarao, Narsingrao on Saturday previous to December 26, 1955 in field belonging to Baga Rao.

anchor.surface_text: On the Saturday previous to the Monday, December 26, 1955, which was the day of the occurrence, there was a quarrel between Baga Rao on one side and Lingarao and Narsingrao on the other in the field said to belong to Baga Rao.

facts.text: Parties reside in village Kollamaddi taluk Sircilla, district Karimnagar.

anchor.surface_text: The parties reside in village Kollamaddi taluk Sircilla, district Karimnagar.

facts.text: On December 26, 1955 at about 7 a.m., Baga Rao proceeding from his village towards Nirmal side.

anchor.surface_text: At about 7 a.m. on the morning of December 26, 1955, Baga Rao had been proceeding from his village towards Nirmal side.

facts.text: Accused lying in wait, appellant fell upon Baga Rao with knife M.O.13, others caught hold.

anchor.surface_text: The accused, who appears to have been lying in wait for Baga Rao, came running from behind and the appellant fell upon Baga Rao with his knife. The other accused persons caught hold of Baga Rao and the appellant inflicted several injuries on his person with his knife  M.O. 13 .

facts.text: Appellant stabbed Baga Rao in neck, abdomen, thigh and other parts, fatal in neck and abdomen.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused overpowered him by catching hold of the different parts of his body, and the appellant stabbed him in the regions of the neck, abdomen, thigh and other parts of his body, the fatal injuries being in the neck and the abdomen.

facts.text: P.W.1 (father's brother of appellant) saw most of occurrence, hid in hut out of fear.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the occurrence, P.W. 1, fathers brother of the appellant, who also was proceeding towards Nirmal, saw most of the occurrence and then, out of fear, hid himself in a hut nearby.

facts.text: P.W.2 (12 year old boy, student 4th standard) saw whole occurrence from few yards, claimed Baga Rao as maternal uncle.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 2-a boy of about 12 years-a student of 4th standard in a Government school, was also proceeding in that direction that morning, and saw the whole occurrence from beginning to end from a short distance of a few yards. This young boy claimed the murdered Baga Rao as his maternal uncle, stating that his mother is the sister of Baga Rao.

facts.text: P.W.6 (wife of deceased) stated P.W.2 distantly related, not son of husband's sister.

anchor.surface_text: But the wife of the murdered man, P.W. 6, stated in cross-examination that P.W. 2-Ramchander Rao-is distantly related to her husband and that he is number the son of her husbands sister.

facts.text: Chatriah (father of deceased, 85 years, D.W.1) disclaimed relationship with P.W.2.

anchor.surface_text: The father of the murdered man, Chatriah, aged about 85 years, who has been examined as defence witness No. 1, disclaimed all relationship with the said P.W. 2, but stated that he is related to Dharmiah, P.W. 1, who is numberother than his full brother.

facts.text: First information report drawn by Police Patel P.W.8 Gopal Rao at 11 a.m. on December 26, naming all four accused.

anchor.surface_text: When P. W. 1 aforesaid informed Gopal Rao  P. W. 8 -Police Patel-about the occurrence, he drew up the first information report at about 11 a.m., on December 26. All the four accused were named as the culprits in the first information report.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector P.W.11 proceeded to spot, prepared inquest report, found throat cut, injuries on stomach, thigh, hand.

anchor.surface_text: He issued that report to the station house, Gambhiraopet, about 5 miles from the place of occurrence. The Sub-Inspector of police, P.W. 11, proceeded to the spot and prepared the inquest report. He found the throat of the deceased cut, besides other injuries on the left side of the stomach and right thigh and three wounds on the left hand.

facts.text: Post mortem report on December 27 confirmed injuries, incised wound on neck cut trachea, oesophagus, jugular vein.

anchor.surface_text: The post mortem report, made the next day, December 27, companyroborated the nature of the injuries stated above, and added that the incised wound across the lower part of the neck, had cut the vital organs like trachea, oesophagus and the jugular vein.

facts.text: Police report under s.173 CrPC submitted January 11, 1956, placed before Magistrate January 12.

anchor.surface_text: The police report under s. 173 of Criminal Procedure Code was made by the investigating police officer on January 11, 1956, and was placed before the Munsiff-Magistrate on January 12.

facts.text: Magistrate examined police officer as W1, eye-witnesses as PW2,3, medical as PW4 around February 15, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsiff-Magistrate appears to have examined the investigating police officer as W. 1, and the two eye-witnesses, Dharmiah and Ramchander Rao, as P.Ws. 2 and 3, and the medical officer as P.W. 4, on or about February 15, 1956.

facts.text: Provisions of ss.173(4) and 207A(3) CrPC not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued, as was admitted by the learned Government Advocate before the High Court, that the provisions of ss. 173 4  and 207A 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure, have number been companyplied with

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on July 15, 1957, dismissed appeal, upheld conviction.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. July 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.

facts.text: Blood-stained knife M.O.13 and garments recovered, human blood stains confirmed by chemical examiner.

anchor.surface_text: Besides their testimony, there is the evidence of the recovery of the blood-stained garments from the houses of the accused persons and the blood-stained knife found near the dead body, and identified in companyrt as belonging to the appellant, which were all found by the chemical examiner, to have stains of human blood.

facts.text: Courts below relied on eye-witnesses corroborated by circumstances, convicted appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below have relied upon the evidence of the eye- witnesses, companyroborated by the incriminating circumstances aforesaid, and have agreed in companyvicting and sentencing the accused as stated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Shall' is directory as mandatory interpretation would defeat purpose of simplifying proceedings; far-reaching effect avoided; analogies to ss.162,360 cured by s.537

holdings.text: The word shall occurring both in sub-s. 4 of s. 173 and sub-s. 3 of s. 207A is not mandatory but only directory
holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission should not render trial wholly ineffective, defeating legislative intent to simplify commitment; prejudice test applies

holdings.text: omission complained of in the instant case should not have a more far-reaching effect than the omission to carry out the provisions of s. 162 or s. 360 of the Code
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee precedents holding similar non-compliances curable under s.537 CrPC

precedents.cited_holding: it was a mere irregularity which could be cured by the provisions of s. 537

precedents.citation: Pulukuri Kotayya and others v. King- Emperor  2

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Pulukuri Kotayya and others v. King- Emperor  2 , the Judicial Committee had to companysider the effect of breach of the statutory provisions of s. 162 of the Code. The following observations of their Lordships, at pages 75-76, are a companyplete answer to the arguments advanced on behalf of the appellant before us, and we respectfully adopt them

precedents.cited_proposition: breach of s. 162 of the Code is an irregularity curable under s. 537 if the trial is conducted substantially in the manner prescribed by the Code
precedents.cited_holding: When a trial is conducted in a manner different from that prescribed by the Code as in N. A. Subramania Iyers case 3 , the trial is bad... The present case falls under s. 537, and their Lordships hold the trial valid notwithstanding the breach of s. 162.

anchor.surface_text: When a trial is companyducted in a, manner different from that prescribed by the Code  as in N. A. Subramania Iyers case  3  , the trial is bad, and numberquestion of curing an irregularity arises but if the trial is companyducted substantially in the manner prescribed by the Code, but some irregularity occurs in the companyrse of such companyduct, the irregularity can be cured under s. 537

precedents.case_name: N. A. Subramania Iyer v. King-Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: where a trial is conducted in a manner different from that prescribed by the Code, the trial is bad and no question of curing irregularity arises

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued, as was admitted by the learned Government Advocate before the High Court, that the provisions of ss. 173 4  and 207A 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure, have not been complied with, and that, as a necessary consequence of those omissions, the entire proceedings and the trial are vitiated.
Hence, in our opinion, there is no ground for interference with the conclusions of the courts below on the merits of the case.

anchor.surface_text: Does such an omission necessarily render the entire proceedings and the trial null and void or is it only an irregularity curable with reference of the provisions of s. 537  a  of the Code ? In other words, are the provisions of S. 173 4 , read with s. 207A 3  mandatory or only directory ?
Hence, in our opinion, there is no ground for interference with the conclusions of the courts below on the merits of the case.
